greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Least k such that the Gaussian integer (2n-1)+ki is squarefull.
comment: We treat only the odd case 2n-1 because for the even case we can always take k=0; that is, for n>0, 2n always has a factor of (1+i)^2. Using quadratic residues mod 25, it can be proved that 0<=a(n)<=12 for all n. The plot shows the squarefull Gaussian integers as black squares.
link: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n=1..1000
T. D. Noe, Plot of the Moebius function for Gaussian Integers
example: a(4)=1 because 7+i has the factor (2+i)^2, but 7+0i has no square factors because it is prime.
mathematica: moebius[z_] := Module[{f, mu}, If[z==0, mu=0, If[Abs[z]==1, mu=1, f=FactorInteger[z, GaussianIntegers->True]; If[Abs[f[[1, 1]]]==1, f=Drop[f, 1]]; mu=1; Do[If[f[[i, 2]]==1, mu=-mu, mu=0], {i, Length[f]}]]]; mu]; Table[k=0; While[z=n+k*I; moebiusMuZ[z]!=0, k++ ]; k, {n, 1, 250, 2}]
xref: Cf. A103226 (Moebius function for Gaussian integers).
results.author: _T. D. Noe_, Jan 26 2005
